description: 1650s, from French épistolaire, from Latin epistolārius, from epistola (“letter”) (English epistle) + -ārius, from Ancient Greek ἐπιστολή (epistolḗ) from ἐπιστέλλω (epistéllō, “I send a message”) from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + στέλλω (stéllō, “I prepare, send”).

adjectives.description: epistolary (comparative more epistolary, superlative most epistolary)

entries.meaning: Of or relating to letters, or the writing of letters.
In the manner of written correspondence.

description: From Middle English pistelarie, from Latin epistolārium, from epistola (“letter”) (English epistle) + -ārium, from Ancient Greek ἐπιστολή (epistolḗ) from ἐπιστέλλω (epistéllō, “I send a message”) from ἐπί (epí, “upon”) + στέλλω (stéllō, “I prepare, send”).

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A Christian liturgical book containing set readings for church services from the New Testament Epistles.
